ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This class was very helpful in providing a starting foundation for the Spanish language.
Basic spanish, enough to order food and generally understand

I gained new reading, writing, speaking, and listening abilities in Spanish. By the end of the semester I could hold basic conversations in Spanish and read simple Spanish texts with decent proficiency.
Learned quite a lot of Spanish within a short timeframe. Although I still am nowhere near fluent, I was impressed by how much I knew after the course. This included vocabulary and grammar skills.
I gained the basis of Spanish from preterite, present progressive, to present. I also learned basic vocab such as greetings, colors, food, school supplies, and buildings.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: In terms of strengths, I appreciated the very detailed syllabus since it was essentially a roadmap for each day and was very explicit in how students could prepare for it. On the other hand, I did not appreciate the multiple quizzes at the very beginning of the semester. It felt very unfair, especially for someone in my situation, to come into an elementary-level language class and be expected to grasp grammar rules and score well on quizzes.

Strengths: You will learn a lot of Spanish in a short period of time. It is very rewarding to gradually begin to understand more complicated phrases and the nuances of the language, and I thought the course did a great job of forcing me to practice my Spanish on a regular basis. Very well-organized course.
Weaknesses: Although the course was solid, it seemed quite intensive and difficult for people who had never been exposed to Spanish before. I think the accessibility of the professor and small class size really helps with this.
Improvements: Although the course moves fast for good reason, it would be nice to have more time to master concepts.

I enjoyed the asynchronous days a lot, as well as the lack of a final exam. This made learning more enjoyable for all students, and less pressurized. The in class activities were fun.

Some weaknesses was that there was a lot of homework per day and grammar points were taught too fast.

The main weakness in this course is how fast we go/how much content we cover in a semester. It is difficult to retain and study it all and if you miss one piece, it messes you up for the next unit. The main strength is that we are encouraged to practice sentence structures in compositions and class conversations.
Had set plans for the week, but sometimes assessments would shift out of order creating confusion

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course to other students. In my experience, the course is structured well, and it is designed to make sure everyone is at least on the same page. I get that it seems intimidating at first, and the workload is a little heavy, but the course is very engaging.
Definitely a good route to get language requirements done, as it efficiently teaches you spanish and isnt too hard.
I would recommend this course to someone who is enthusiastic about learning Spanish. If you are not motivated to learn and genuinely care about learning the language it will be quite painful.
Yes, if they are interested in learning Spanish from scratch and are prepared for the heavy workload.

I would if they want to learn Spanish and take it seriously for future study abroad trips or certification. However, if it's just another language to pick up after you're already certified in a different one, I do not recommend it.
Yes I would. I had a great instructor and the material learned gave me a good basic understanding of the language
